subject: Re: Automatic JUnit test creation
msgSnippet: There are two roles for automatic testgen, one is that you only stubbed out your api, I admit, not true TDD by a long way. The other use is that your
messageBody:
There are two roles for automatic testgen, one is that you only
stubbed out your api, I admit, not true TDD by a long way. The other
use is that your application builds upon another jar that has little
to no tests. This project is in its early stages but one aim is to
create tests cheaply where they were none before.

regards
calvin

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Bradley, Todd" <todd.bradley@p...> wrote:
> Not everyone uses JUnit for TDD, I suppose.
>
> Nowadays that I think in TDD, I can barely imagine a tool to write my
> unit tests for me, any more than I can imagine a tool that will write my
> code for me.
>
> Hmm. Actually, now that I think about it, having a tool that writes my
> code for me in order to make my TDD unit tests pass seems MORE feasible
> than what Chris is proposing.
>
>
> Todd.
>
>
>
>
> ________________________________
>
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Chris Dollin
> Sent: Tuesday, August 02, 2005 2:06 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Automatic JUnit test creation
>
>
> On Tuesday 02 August 2005 00:12, Calvin Austin wrote:
> > Wouldn't it be nice if Junit could do all the hard work and
> create the
> > tests for you?
>
> I don't see how it could - when I start writing tests, there is
> no code for anything to create tests /from/.
>
> What am I missing?
>
> --
> Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
> predicting self-predictors' predictions is predictably
> unpredictable.
>
>
>
